facts.text: The appellant, a resident of Palwal in Gurgaon District, committed house trespass and tried to outrage the modesty of a girl aged 7 years.
The appellant was sent up for trial before the Magistrate, First Class, Palwal.

The Magistrate convicted the appellant under ss. 451 and 354 of the Indian Penal Code on May 31, 1962, and sentenced him to six months rigorous imprisonment under each count, to run concurrently, and imposed a fine of Rs. 200/- under s. 451 IPC with two months rigorous imprisonment in default.
The appellant was 16 years old at the time of his conviction.
The Probation of Offenders Act, 1958 was extended to Gurgaon District on September 1, 1962.
The appellant preferred an appeal to the Additional Sessions Judge, Gurgaon, who dismissed it on September 22, 1962.
Neither the appellant nor the Additional Sessions Judge relied on or exercised powers under the Probation of Offenders Act.
The appellant filed a revision in the Punjab High Court, Criminal Revision No. 1172 of 1962, which was dismissed in limine on September 27, 1962. No ground under the Act was taken.

After dismissal of revision, appellant filed Criminal Miscellaneous Petition No. 793 of 1962 requesting High Court to exercise jurisdiction under s.11 of the Act and pass orders under ss.3,4 or 6, which was dismissed.
Appellant filed petition under Art. 134(1)(c) of Constitution for certificate, one ground being High Court should act under s.11, which was dismissed.
Special leave to appeal to Supreme Court granted.

legal_issues.text: Whether an appellate or revisional court can exercise power under s.6 of the Probation of Offenders Act, 1958 in respect of an accused convicted by the trial court before the Act was extended to the area.
Whether the Supreme Court can exercise the same power under s.11(1) of the Act.

petitioner_arguments.text: Having regard to the admitted facts, the High Court should have acted under s.11 of the Act and released the appellant on probation of good conduct instead of sending him to prison.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Sections 3, 4, 6, 11 of Probation of Offenders Act, 1958

respondent_arguments.text: The Act is not retrospective in operation and therefore does not apply to the appellant convicted before it came into force in Gurgaon District.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Sections 6, 11 of Probation of Offenders Act, 1958; Article 20 Constitution

respondent_arguments.text: Neither s.11 nor s.6 can be invoked; appellant precluded by default in not raising plea earlier.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Sections 6, 11 of Probation of Offenders Act, 1958

court_reasoning.text: The Act is a beneficial legislation for reform, not retrospective in punishing sense but applicable to pending cases; s.11(1) empowers appellate/revisional courts to make orders under the Act, including s.6, even if trial court could not.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Phraseology of s.11(1) is wide enough; 'court by which the person is found guilty' includes appellate/revisional courts confirming conviction.

court_reasoning.text: Ramji Missar v. State of Bihar supports that appellate courts can make orders under s.6 for first time.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No anomaly if applied to pending appeals; avoids illogical distinctions.

court_reasoning.text: Supreme Court can direct High Court to comply with s.6, requiring probation officer report; remand to High Court as best course.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Mandatory to call for probation report before sentencing under 21-year-old.

court_reasoning.text: Late raising of point excused as courts ignored mandatory provisions; Act recently extended.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Courts bound by Act despite appellant's delay.

holdings.text: Appellate court or High Court in revision can exercise power under s.11 to make order under s.6(1) even if trial court convicted before Act's extension.
Supreme Court can direct High Court to do so, subject to s.6 conditions including probation report.

precedents_cited.case_name: Ramji Missar v. State of Bihar
precedents_cited.relevance: Appellate court can make order under s.6(1) for first time even if trial court could not; wide interpretation of s.11(1)

statutes_cited.name: Probation of Offenders Act, 1958
statutes_cited.relevance: Empowers courts including appellate/revisional to release young offenders on probation instead of imprisonment; mandatory consideration for under 21

statutes_cited.name: Indian Penal Code
statutes_cited.relevance: Offences of house trespass and outraging modesty of woman; punishable with imprisonment not life

statutes_cited.name: Code of Criminal Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: Mentioned in petition as alternative relief

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Art.20 on ex post facto laws; Art.134(1)(c) for certificate; Art.136 for special leave

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; orders of High Court, Sessions Judge and Magistrate set aside to extent of sentence; matter remanded to High Court to make order under s.6 of Probation of Offenders Act after calling probation officer report, or remand to Sessions Court. Guilt finding not questioned.
outcome.relief_granted: Remand for consideration under s.6 of Act

key_quotes.text: The Act is a milestone in the progress of the modern liberal trend of reform in the field of penology.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Describes purpose of Probation of Offenders Act

key_quotes.text: Notwithstanding anything contained in the Code or any other law, an order under this Act may be made by any Court empowered to try and sentence the offender to imprisonment and also by the High Court or any other Court when the case comes before it on appeal or in revision.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Quotes s.11(1); basis for holding appellate power

key_quotes.text: When an appellate court or a revisional court confirms a conviction made by a trial court... it finds the accused guilty.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Interprets 'court by which the person is found guilty' in s.6(1)
